properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Locations: western Newfoundland from Port aux Basques to the Bay of Islands. Time span: tonight continuing through Thursday. Remarks: Flurries will continue overnight, with areas of snow squall activity developing as cold westerly winds continue. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-19T19:19:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T03:20:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3565587692.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow will continue for extreme northeastern portions of Saskatchewan. The heavy snow will end this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T08:54:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T21:28:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3190522687.2020
Area: Wollaston Lake - Collins Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is no longer expected. ###

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A band of very heavy snow will develop through central Alberta this evening. Visibility will be reduced in the heavy snow. The northern extent of the heavy snow is expected to be along Highway 16, this includes the city of Edmonton. Total snowfall amounts are expected to vary across the city with the heaviest amounts falling in the south. The snow will move eastwards into Saskatchewan Thursday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T14:33:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T22:34:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3012384611.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle continues in Flin Flon and Thompson this evening but should begin to taper off after midnight. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T13:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T03:23:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3318932730.2020
Area: South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House, Snow Lake and Herb Lake Landing, Flin Flon Cranberry Portage and Grass River Prov. Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog will persist until Thursday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T19:23:49-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally near 10 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: King's County P.E.I., Iles-de-la-Madeleine, and western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Remarks: Snow squall activity is expected to develop this evening as cold northwesterly winds strengthen. Snow squalls and flurries will taper off from west to east through the day on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T18:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-19T03:17:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3950390317.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system moving across northern BC is bringing snow to the Fort Nelson region. Snow has continued through the night, and the band of heavier snowfall will remain over the northern sections of the region this morning. Further snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are expected in the Fort Nelson region before the snow eases to light snow late this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T07:26:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T15:27:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3992914781.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Locations: along the Burgeo Highway. Time span: overnight tonight through the day Thursday. Remarks: Flurries will continue overnight, with areas of snow squall activity developing as cold westerly winds strengthen. Snow squalls are expected to occur inland, mainly affecting the Burgeo Highway, with just a few flurries along the south coast. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow with just a few kilometres are common. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow continues across parts of northern Manitoba. The snow has been falling quite heavy through the day in a few localities. This afternoon, snow began to taper off throughout west-central Manitoba. The snow will continue to subside throughout east-central and extreme northern Manitoba this evening. Regions in central Manitoba may see some freezing drizzle after the snow departs. The freezing drizzle risk will diminish in the evening and through the overnight. Please refer to local forecasts for additional details on timing and snowfall amounts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-19T07:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-18T21:18:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3372062129.2020
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Gillam, Shamattawa
properties.Author: Environment Canada
